row.entry: This rule complements the requirement to serve affidavits (see UCPR r 10.2 ). It provides for the cross-examination of deponents and contingently precludes the use of affidavits where the deponent is not available for cross-examination.

entry.emph: Persons who may make affidavits — Rule 35.3

row.entry: This rule prescribes the eligible deponents of affidavits made on behalf of incapable persons, corporations, associations, represented persons and the Crown. It makes specific provision for affidavits in particular kinds of Local Court proceedings.

These rules govern the formal content of affidavits and any accompanying annexures and exhibits. They stipulate that exhibits to affidavits must be produced for inspection. Leave is required to use affidavits which are irregular in form.

entry.emph: Affidavits by deponents unable to read — Rule 35.7

row.entry: This rule prevents the use of affidavits by relevant deponents unless they either comply with section 27A of the Oaths Act or the court is otherwise satisfied the deponent understood the contents of the affidavit.
This rule requires affidavits of service to identify, but not annex copies of, the documents served.

This Part applies to all courts in Schedule 1 of the CP Act: see r 1.5 and Sch 1. This part applies to criminal proceedings in SCA Third Schedule and to Div 2 of Pt 75 of the SCR (summary jurisdiction): see SCR Pt 75 r 3.

The Part is based on the former SCR Part 38, DCR Part 30 and LCR Part 25. Some minor aspects of the former Supreme Court rules have been omitted (eg, affidavit being in first person, limit on length (50 pages). The rules expressly require written notice where a deponent is to be cross examined.
Affidavit evidence at an earlier stage of the proceedings ‥ [35.2.5]
Cross-examination of deponent — entitlement by written notice ‥ [35.2.10]
Cross-examination of deponent, written notice required ‥ [r 35.2]
Death of deponent, use of affidavit despite ‥ [r 35.2(3)]
Discretionary admission of affidavits where deponent unavailable for cross-examination ‥ [35.2.20]
Exhibits, to be produced for inspection but not filed ‥ [r 35.6(5) and (6)]
Irregularity, leave required to use affidavit containing ‥ [r 35.1]
Leave required to use late served affidavits ‥ [35.9.10]
Leave to use affidavit containing irregularities ‥ [35.1.15]
Oral evidence in chief where deponent required for cross examination ‥ [35.2.25]
Persons who may make affidavit (for corporation or incapable person etc) ‥ [r 35.3]
Required and permissible use of affidavit evidence ‥ [35.1.10]
Rules requiring affidavits to be filed ‥ [35.9.20]
Service, form and contents of affidavit ‥ [r 35.8]
Service of affidavits (reasonable time before use) ‥ [r 35.2]
Weight of evidence where deponent not cross-examined ‥ [35.2.40]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.1] r 35.1 Irregularity does not invalidate affidavit (cf SCR Part 38, rule 5; DCR Part 30, rule 5; LCR Part 25, rule 5)

leg:heading.title: Irregularity does not invalidate affidavit (cf SCR Part 38, rule 5; DCR Part 30, rule 5; LCR Part 25, rule 5)

p.text: An affidavit may, with the leave of the court, be used despite any irregularity in form.
Legislation cited in [35.1.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Interpretation Act 1987 s 80.
(NSW) Oaths Act 1900.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995.
The approved forms are Form 40: Affidavit and Form 41: Affidavit of service.

Strict adherence to the prescribed form is not essential: see also the Interpretation Act 1987 s 80 ; Fastlink Calling Pty Ltd v Macquarie Telecom Pty Ltd (2008) 26 ACLC 374; 217 FLR 366; [2008] NSWSC 299; BC200802264 at [28] .

Some provisions of the Oaths Act 1900 and the Evidence Act 1995 deal with the contents of affidavits when there is no comprehensive statutory prescription for the formal contents of an affidavit: Fastlink Calling Pty Ltd v Macquarie Telecom Pty Ltd, above at [15].

The essential requirement is that the person appreciates the nature and purpose of the document and accepts responsibility for the contents of the document by way of formal oath (in the case of an affidavit) or affirmation. For that reason it is proper to require that the standard form alternatives “oath/affirm” and “sworn/affirmed” actually be completed by deleting the alternative which is inappropriate: Zorbas v Sidiropoulous (No 2) [2009] NSWCA 197; BC200905954 at [97]–[98] per Young JA; Spinoccia Compressor & Air Tools Sales and Service Pty Ltd v Challenger Managed Investments Ltd (2010) 78 ATR 185; [2010] NSWSC 1310; BC201008530 at [15] . If there is doubt about whether a proffered affidavit has in fact been duly sworn it is permissible to receive evidence of the circumstances of its making and attestation: Fastlink Calling Pty Ltd v Macquarie Telecom Pty Ltd, above at [30]; Micar Group Pty Ltd v Insul-Trade Llc (2010) 244 FLR 403; [2010] NSWSC 1391; BC201009026 at [14]–[19] and [34]–[35].
There is no express requirement in the UCPR to provide a residential address: Short v Burn [2012] NSWSC 695; BC201204754 (address provided though not a residential one; affidavit not irregular).

level.toc-caption: [35.1.10] Required and permissible use of affidavit evidence

heading.title: Required and permissible use of affidavit evidence

p.text: Evidence in all interlocutory proceedings must be given by affidavit, unless the court otherwise orders: r 31.2. The court can direct that trial evidence be given by affidavit: r 31.1(3) and ss 29 and 31 of the Evidence Act 1995. In limited circumstances, proceedings may be commenced by affidavit: rr 6.2(1), 25.2(1) and 31.2; and affidavits may be ordered to stand as pleadings in the proceedings: see r 6.6(3)(a). Affidavits are required by the UCPR in various circumstances including the verification of pleadings: rr 14.22–14.24; discovery: rr 21.4(1)(a) and 21.4(2); and answers to interrogatories: rr 22.3(2)(c) and 22.4(1)(a).

level.toc-caption: [35.1.15] Leave to use affidavit containing irregularities

p.text: Legislation cited in [35.1.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Oaths Act 1900 ss 11A, 12, 13, 26.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 r 35.3A–35.8.

heading.title: Leave to use affidavit containing irregularities

p.text: Two questions arise in relation to the use of an irregular document under the present rule. The first question is whether the document is an affidavit. The second is whether leave should be granted despite the formal irregularity. There is no definition of “affidavit” in the CPA or the UCPR. The required formalities appear to be those indicated by the Oaths Act ss 11A , 12 , 13 and 26 namely (i) the making of an oath or affirmation and (ii) the attesting presence of a competent person. Compliance with those requirements should be patent in the affidavit, but they may also be proved by admissible extrinsic evidence: Fastlink Calling Pty Ltd v Macquarie Telecom Pty Ltd (2008) 217 FLR 366; 26 ACLC 374; [2008] NSWSC 299; BC200802264 at [30]–[38]. Unless there is admissible evidence of compliance so as to justify the document being characterised as an affidavit, no question of leave arises under the present rule.

The present rule does not alter the ordinary rules of evidence that apply to the admissibility of both affidavit and oral evidence. The irregularities which are properly capable of justifying the grant of leave under the present rule are limited to matters of form — such as those contained in UCPR r 35.3A–35.8 and see Court Forms, Precedents & Pleadings NSW, LexisNexis, Sydney, 1989 to date (looseleaf), guide card “Affidavits” at [757]. Leave does not enlarge the potential admissibility of the contents of the affidavit. Fundamentally, the affidavit evidence must be relevant. Generally it should use direct speech in recording statements by other people (although indirect speech is not necessarily inadmissible): LMI Australasia Pty Ltd v Baulderstone Hornibrook Pty Ltd (2001) 53 NSWLR 31; [2001] NSWSC 688; BC200104748 ; see Court Forms, Precedents & Pleadings NSW, LexisNexis, Sydney, 1989 to date (looseleaf), guide card “Affidavits” at [660]. Hearsay statements, and opinion evidence, should not be included unless there is a proper basis for their admissibility.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.2] r 35.2 Cross-examination of deponent (cf SCR Part 38, rule 9; DCR Part 30, rule 9; LCR Part 25, rule 10)

leg:heading.title: Cross-examination of deponent (cf SCR Part 38, rule 9; DCR Part 30, rule 9; LCR Part 25, rule 10)

p.text: A party may, by written notice served on the party serving or proposing to use an affidavit, require the attendance for cross-examination of the person by whom the affidavit has been made.
Such notice is to be given a reasonable time before the time at which the person is required to attend for cross-examination.

If reasonable notice of such a requirement has been given in respect of an affidavit, and the deponent does not attend for examination, the affidavit may not be used unless the deponent is dead or unless the court orders otherwise.
If a person making an affidavit is cross-examined, the party using the affidavit may re-examine the person.

level.toc-caption: [35.2.5] Affidavit evidence at an earlier stage of the proceedings

heading.title: Affidavit evidence at an earlier stage of the proceedings

p.text: Any evidence taken in the proceedings can be used in subsequent interlocutory proceedings, on an assessment of damages and, with leave, in relation to proof of particular facts: see r 31.8. In addition, affidavits filed by a party at an earlier stage may be read at a later stage: Chambers v Bryant (1843) 12 LJQB 139; Re Turnbull (1853) 22 LJ Ch 1055. Some older authorities query whether this can only occur by consent: see Perkins v Slater (1875) 1 Ch D 83 ; Johnston v Matthews (1893) 19 VLR 638 ; and Prangley v Evans (1896) 17 LR (NSW) L 416. But it is difficult to see that such a limitation is consistent with principle. Provided an affidavit has been served, and the opposing parties have been given reasonable notice of the evidence intended to be relied on for the purpose of the particular hearing, the entitlement to rely on particular affidavits could not properly be restricted by reference to the date when they were sworn or filed.

level.toc-caption: [35.2.10] Cross examination of deponent — entitlement by written notice

heading.title: Cross examination of deponent — entitlement by written notice

p.text: The party intending to rely on any affidavit must call the deponent at the hearing if an opposing party gives notice requiring the deponent’s attendance for cross-examination. The rule requires written notice to be served. But no document need be filed and in many cases the requirement for service of written notice would be satisfied by an email request: see rr 3.8 and 10.5(2)(c) of the UCPR. The party receiving the notice is not entitled to conduct money to secure the deponent's attendance.
Legislation cited in [35.2.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 63, 67.

Rule 35.2(3) makes it clear that an affidavit may be read even though the deponent has died: Estex Clothing Manufacturers Pty Ltd v Ellis and Goldstein Ltd (1967) 116 CLR 254 at 263; 40 ALJR 515 and see Curley v Duff (1985) 2 NSWLR 716 ; Tanswell v Scurrah (1865) 11 LT 701; Abadom v Abadom (1857) 24 Beav 243; 53 ER 351 ; Davies v Otty (1865) 35 Beav 308; 55 ER 875 and Phipson on Evidence, 12th ed, para 1591. Even apart from the present rule evidence from a deceased deponent may be admissible under ss 63 and 67 of the Evidence Act 1995: Americana Leadership College Pty Ltd v Coll [2003] NSWSC 59; BC200300329 (affidavit filed in previous proceedings — deponent deceased).

level.toc-caption: [35.2.20] Discretionary admission of affidavits where deponent unavailable for cross-examination

heading.title: Discretionary admission of affidavits where deponent unavailable for cross-examination

p.text: If a deponent is not made available for cross-examination required by proper notice, their affidavit cannot be relied on unless the court grants leave under the present rule: Comet Products UK Ltd v Hawkex Plastics Ltd [1971] 2 QB 67 at 74; [1971] 1 All ER 1141 ; Bonhote v Henderson [1895] 1 Ch 742 at 749–50 (infirm deponent); Clyne v Law Society of New South Wales (NSWCA, Kirby P, Mahoney and Clarke JJA, 4 September 1987, unreported, BC8701170). Leave may be appropriate in a variety of circumstances — including the following:

where the witness’ evidence relates to matters that are not substantially in dispute, or where any dispute does not require to be resolved by cross-examination: Cairns v Cairns [2006] NSWSC 364; BC200603146 at [12] (plaintiff in family provision proceedings refusing to submit to further cross-examination); contrast Caldar v Public Trustee of NSW [2005] NSWCA 166; BC200503083 (idiosyncratic objection to opposing party’s participation in the proceedings — leave refused);

where terms are imposed excluding contentious parts of the affidavit evidence where the absence of cross examination would give rise to a risk of unfair prejudice: Vella v Wah Lai Investment (Australia) Pty Ltd [2004] NSWSC 583; BC200404326 (deponent unavailable as a result of recent family bereavement overseas);
where the witness is terminally ill and their unavailability is not otherwise attributable to the party calling the witness: Citibank Ltd v Liu [2002] NSWSC 886; BC200205813 ;

where terms are imposed requiring the witness to submit to written interrogatories and produce any documents required by the opposing party: Clyne v Law Society of New South Wales (NSWCA, Kirby P, Mahoney and Clarke JJA, CA 344 of 1985, 4 Sept 1987, unreported, BC8701170);
where the proposed cross-examination sought additional information without challenging the content of the affidavit evidence: Fermiscan Ltd v James [2009] NSWSC 474; BC200904805 s.

See further as to the exercise of discretion under this rule: Shea v Green (1886) 2 TLR 533 ; The Parisian (1887) 13 PD 16 ; Re O'Brien [1923] SASR 411 ; Re Constantine [1947] SASR 415 ; and Re O'Neil [1972] VR 327 at 333 ; Bayer AG v Minister for Health (Cth) (1988) 13 IPR 225 at 296 (televised evidence of overseas witness); Garcin v Amerindo Investment Advisors Ltd [1991] 4 All ER 655; [1991] 1 WLR 1140 (televised evidence of overseas witness); Laporte Group Australia Ltd v Vatselias (NSWSC, Young J, 25 November 1991, unreported, BC9101405) (cross-examination of overseas witness via television link); Markisic v United States of America [2006] NSWSC 839; BC200606376 (telephone cross-examination of overseas witness) and see also r 31.3. In an appropriate case the party desiring to cross-examine can be ordered to meet the expenses of attendance of the witness in the first instance: Stanley-Hill v Kool [1982] 1 NSWLR 460 at 465 .

level.toc-caption: [35.2.25] Oral evidence in chief where deponent required for cross examination

heading.title: Oral evidence in chief where deponent required for cross examination

p.text: When the deponent is called at the hearing, and unless the judge gives leave to call oral evidence, their oral evidence in chief merely identifies them (by giving their name, address and occupation) and any of their affidavits that are relied upon. Unless the party calling the witness is aware of corrections the deponent wishes to make, it is unnecessary for the deponent either to be asked whether, or to state that, they adhere to their affidavit evidence and such a question has, in any event, been held to be inadmissible: AWA Ltd v Radio 3XY Pty Ltd (NSWSC, McLelland J, 21 June 1991, unreported).

The cross-examination is not limited to the matters contained in the affidavit, but the deponent may be cross-examined on any relevant matter or as to credit: Muir v Harper (1900) 25 VLR 534 ; Keogh v Dalgety & Co Ltd (1917) 17 SR (NSW) 573 ; see more particularly [29.5.70] .

Unless a special order has been made, a party to a proceeding where the evidence is to be taken on affidavit is not obliged to read an affidavit which they have filed: Leaders Shoes (Aust) Pty Ltd v National Insurance Co of New Zealand Ltd [1968] 1 NSWR 344; (1968) 86 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 388 ; RCA Corp v Custom Cleared Sales Pty Ltd (1978) 19 ALR 123; [1978] FSR 576 . Similarly, there is no entitlement to cross-examine the deponent of an affidavit which has been filed but not read: SACMI Co-operativa Meccanici Imola v Riramo (NSWSC, Allen M, 4 June 1980, unreported, BC8031038), distinguishing Clarke v Law (1855) 2 K & J 28; 69 ER 680 and Re Quartz Hill Co; Ex parte Young (1882) 21 Ch D 642 . However, there is no privilege in relation to affidavits that have been filed and served: Austress Freyssinet Pty Ltd v Marlin International Pty Ltd [2002] NSWSC 958; BC200206111 ; Dubbo City Council v Barrett [2003] NSWCA 267; BC200305990 (contrast [31.4.20] in relation to some witness statements; Ingot Capital Investments Pty Ltd v Macquarie Equity Capital Markets Ltd [2004] NSWSC 40; BC200400230 , in relation to affidavits filed in other proceedings). Consequently, provided the deponent can be made available for cross-examination if required (Leaders Shoes (Aust) Pty Ltd v National Insurance Co of New Zealand Ltd [1968] 1 NSWR 344 at 346; (1968) 86 WN (Pt 1) (NSW) 388 ; Leaders Shoes (Aust) Pty Ltd v Liverpool and London and Globe Insurance Co Ltd [1968] 1 NSWR 279 at 280 ), a party may read affidavits which have been filed by the opposing party: Price v Hayman (1838) 4 M & W 8; 150 ER 1321; Re Margetson and Jones [1897] 2 Ch 314 at 319, 320 ; Barristers' Board of Western Australia v Tranter Corp Pty Ltd [1976] WAR 65 . However, and subject to a qualification in relation to admissions, an affidavit filed by an opposing party cannot simply be tendered as a documentary exhibit: Burns Philp Trustee Co Ltd v Memsie Pastoral Co Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Needham J, 22 March 1984, unreported). But if a party has made an admission in an affidavit, the part of that affidavit containing the admission may be tendered (without the affidavit being “read”: Wimpole v McIlwraith [1923] VLR 553 . (The position is different with respect to an affidavit of a mere witness — who cannot make admissions on behalf of a party: Prangley v Evans (1896) 17 LR (NSW) L 416; Leaders Shoes (Aust) Pty Ltd v National Insurance Co of New Zealand Ltd, above). However, the tenderer cannot prevent reference being made to other parts of the affidavits which may provide a relevant qualification of, or context for, the admission: Re Vassis; Ex parte Leung (1986) 9 FCR 518 at 520; 64 ALR 407 ; Barristers' Board of Western Australia v Tranter Corp Pty Ltd, above.

level.toc-caption: [35.2.40] Weight of evidence where deponent not cross-examined

heading.title: Weight of evidence where deponent not cross-examined

p.text: If an affidavit is used (with leave) despite the unavailability of the deponent for cross-examination, the evidence is untested and must be evaluated (and discounted) accordingly — irrespective of the reason (ill health, chance or culpable default) for the witness' unavailability: Clyne v Law Society of New South Wales (NSWCA, Kirby P, Mahoney and Clarke JJA, 4 September 1987, unreported, BC8701170) (especially per Mahoney JA); Fexuto Pty Ltd v Bosnjak Holdings Pty Ltd (1998) 28 ACSR 688 at 698 ; Re O'Neil [1972] VR 327 at 333 . If an available deponent is not cross-examined, the principles discussed in [29.5.50] (the rule in Browne v Dunn (1893) 6 R 67 ) apply, and the failure may constitute an implied acceptance of the witness' evidence. Compliance with Browne v Dunn will require more extensive cross-examination in a case where all the evidence is given orally, than is necessary in a case where the substance of the evidence proposed to be given by each side is notified in advance by affidavit or statement. The serving of affidavits in chief will often give the necessary notice to the other party and its advisers that a party proposes to rely upon certain matters particularly where the other party takes the opportunity, in its own affidavit in response, to reply to that allegation. Even when there has been an exchange of affidavits or statements, the rule in Browne v Dunn will require a cross-examining counsel to put to a witness the implications which counsel proposes to submit can be drawn from the evidence, if those implications are not obvious from the evidence, or from other pre-trial procedures, or the course of the case: West v Mead [2003] NSWSC 161 at [93]–[100]; BC200301515 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.3] r 35.3 Persons who may make affidavit (cf SCR Part 24, rule 7; DCR Part 22A, rule 7)

leg:heading.title: Persons who may make affidavit (cf SCR Part 24, rule 7; DCR Part 22A, rule 7)

p.text: If a party is required by these rules to file an affidavit or to verify any matter by affidavit, such an affidavit may be made by the party or:
if the party is a person under legal incapacity, by the party’s tutor, or
if the party is a corporation, by a member or officer of the corporation or (if it is in liquidation) by its liquidator, or
if the party is a body of persons lawfully suing or being sued:
in the name of the body, or
in the name of any member or officer of the body, or
in the name of any other person associated with the body,
by a member or officer of the body, or
if the party is the Crown or an officer of the Crown being sued in his or her official capacity, by an officer of the Crown, or
if the proceedings are being brought in the plaintiff’s name by some other person pursuant to a right of subrogation:
by that other person, or
if that other person is a corporation, by a member or officer of the corporation or (if it is in liquidation) by its liquidator.
[subr (1) am Amendment 8 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 7 April 2006]
Such an affidavit may also be made, in relation to proceedings in the Local Court:

by the party’s solicitor, or by a commercial agent with respect to debt collection (within the meaning of the Commercial Agents and Private Inquiry Agents Act 2004), in relation only to proceedings on an application for:
an instalment order, or
an order for examination, or
a writ of execution, or
a garnishee order, or
default judgment (but only in the Small Claims Division), or

by a person holding a licence as a real estate agent, strata managing agent or on-site residential property manager within the meaning of the Property, Stock and Business Agents Act 2002 in relation only to:
proceedings on an application referred to in paragraph (a), or
the filing of a certificate under section 51 of the Consumer, Trader and Tenancy Tribunal Act 2001.

[subr (2) am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[40], effective 15 August 2005 ; Amendment 8 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 7 April 2006; Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[14], effective 9 June 2006 ; am Amendment 19 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 2[1], effective 6 July 2009]
If more than one person is qualified to make an affidavit on behalf of a party, it is sufficient for such an affidavit to be made (subject to subrules (1) and (2)) by any one or more of them.
[subr (2A) insrt Amendment 17 of 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[4], effective 5 October 2007]
Subject to any order of the court, the person by whom an affidavit is made must be a person having knowledge of the facts deposed to in the affidavit.
If an affidavit is made by a person other than the party required to file or verify the affidavit, the affidavit must set out the facts that qualify the person to make the affidavit.
Subject to subrule (1), a requirement of these rules for an affidavit as to any matter may be satisfied by separate affidavits made by separate persons in relation to separate aspects of that matter.
[r 35.3 am Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[39], effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [35.3.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Mental Health Act 2007.

A ‘person under legal incapacity’ is defined in s 3(1) of the CPA. The definition does not include prisoners who require leave to commence proceedings under s 4 of the Felons (Civil Proceedings) Act 1981). The definition does includes: (a) a child under the age of 18 years; and (b) an involuntary patient or forensic patient within the meaning of the Mental Health Act 2007 ; and (c) a person under guardianship within the meaning of the Guardianship Act 1987; and (d) a protected person within the meaning of the Protected Estates Act 1983; and (e) an incommunicate person, whose physical or mental disability renders them unable to receive communications, or express their wishes for their property or affairs. If it appears to the person taking the affidavit that the proposed deponent is not competent to take an oath (because of an apparent incapacity to hear, understand and communicate) specific provisions apply. If the person taking the affidavit tells the proposed deponent that it is important to tell the truth, the deponent declares they will not tell lies, and the person taking the affidavit is satisfied that the proposed deponent understands and is able to respond rationally, the affidavit is admissible as if it had been taken on oath: Oaths Act 1900 s 32(1)–(3).
Legislation cited in [35.3.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Oaths Act 1900 s 26(1)(b) and (c).

Affidavits sworn outside New South Wales may be sworn before a person having authority to administer an oath in that place or before a notary public or British or Australian consular officer: Oaths Act 1900, s 26(1)(b) and (c) .
Legislation cited in [35.3.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Oaths Act 1900 s 29.
Knowingly false statements in an affidavit render the deponent liable to prosecution for perjury: s 29 of the Oaths Act 1900.

Pursuant to the Oaths Act 1900, ss 26 and 27, affidavits for use in connection with legal proceedings may be sworn before a legal practitioner (ie, a solicitor or a barrister), a Justice of the Peace or a person authorised under s 27(2) of that Act (a “commissioner for affidavits”. A person who administers an oath, or accepts an affirmation, in relation to an affidavit, ought not permit the swearing of an affidavit they are aware is false. Nor should they permit an affidavit to be sworn unless they are satisfied the deponent understands the nature of an oath or affirmation, and the contents of the affidavit: Bourke v Davis (1889) 44 Ch D 110 at 126 .
The heading to an affidavit must include the name of the deponent and the date on which the affidavit is made.
[r 35.3A insrt Amendment 11 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[21], effective 8 December 2006]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.4] r 35.4 Format of affidavit dealing with more than one matter (cf SCR Part 38, rule 2; DCR Part 30, rule 2; LCR Part 25, rule 2)

leg:heading.title: Format of affidavit dealing with more than one matter (cf SCR Part 38, rule 2; DCR Part 30, rule 2; LCR Part 25, rule 2)

p.text: If the body of an affidavit alleges or otherwise deals with more than one matter:
it must be divided into paragraphs, and
each matter must, so far as convenient, be put in a separate paragraph, and
the paragraphs must be numbered consecutively.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.5] r 35.5 Alterations (cf SCR Part 38, rule 3; DCR Part 30, rule 3; LCR Part 25, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Alterations (cf SCR Part 38, rule 3; DCR Part 30, rule 3; LCR Part 25, rule 3)

p.text: If there is any interlineation, erasure or other alteration in the jurat or body of an affidavit, the affidavit may not be used, except by leave of the court, unless the person before whom the affidavit is sworn initials the alteration and, in the case of an erasure, rewrites in the margin of the affidavit any words or figures written on the erasure and signs or initials them.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.6] r 35.6 Annexures and exhibits (cf SCR Part 38, rule 4; DCR Part 30, rule 4; LCR Part 25, rule 4)

leg:heading.title: Annexures and exhibits (cf SCR Part 38, rule 4; DCR Part 30, rule 4; LCR Part 25, rule 4)

p.text: A document to be used in conjunction with an affidavit may be made:
an annexure to the affidavit, or
an exhibit to the affidavit.
An annexure to an affidavit must be identified as such by a certificate endorsed on the annexure (and not on a page separate from the annexure) signed by the person before whom the affidavit is made.
The pages of an affidavit, together with any annexures, must be consecutively numbered in a single series of numbers.
An exhibit to an affidavit must be identified as such by a certificate attached to the exhibit entitled in the same manner as the affidavit and signed by the person before whom the affidavit is made.
An exhibit to an affidavit must not be filed.
If any other party so requires, a party who serves an affidavit to which a document is an exhibit:
must produce the document for inspection by that other party, or
must provide a photocopy of the document to that other party, or
must produce the document at some convenient place to enable it to be photocopied by that other party.
The approved form for exhibit certificate is Form 42.

The distinction between an annexure and an exhibit is discussed by Kennedy J with reference to texts and authorities in Robowash Pty Ltd v Robowash Finance Pty Ltd (2000) 158 FLR 338; 19 ACLC 393; [2000] WASCA 409; BC200007849 [14] , citing inter alia Tebbutt v Ambler (1839) 7 Dowl 674 at 675 per Coleridge J; R E Daniell, Daniells Chancery Forms, 7th ed, Stevens & Sons, London, 1932, p 13, Wallwork and Anderson JJ agreeing. The determination as to whether a document to be used in conjunction with an affidavit ought to be annexed or exhibited is by reference to “convenience”. “Convenience” refers to practicality having regard to such matters as the size, condition and bulk of the document, and the expense of copying: Hassle v Cmr of Patents (1987) 9 IPR 565 at 567–8 .

Annexures must be identified as such by a certificate endorsed on the annexure (and not on a page separate from the annexure) signed by the person before whom the affidavit is sworn: r 35.6(2). The certificate is in words to the following effect “This and the following [number] pages is the annexure marked '[letter]' to the affidavit of [name of deponent] sworn/affirmed on [date] before me”. There is no need for the annexure to be signed by the deponent of the affidavit. An exhibit to an affidavit must be identified by certificate: r 35.6(4). The certificate should be entitled in the same manner as the affidavit. Where the parties are numerous it is often good practice to abbreviate the title. It is convenient in the exhibit note to include the witness's initials and a number, because if there are numerous affidavits it may be difficult to identify the affidavit to which they relate. Similarly where a deponent swears several affidavits it is convenient to pick up the exhibit number where the last affidavit left off. Exhibits are not filed: r 35(6)(5); see also Robowash Pty Ltd v Robowash Finance Pty Ltd (2000) 158 FLR 338; 19 ACLC 393; [2000] WASCA 409; BC200007849 at [15] per Kennedy J, Wallwork and Anderson JJ agreeing, referring to Carter v Roberts [1903] 2 Ch 312 at 316 per Byrne.

Where annexure is “inconvenient” (eg, where there are numerous documents) the document may be made an exhibit to the affidavit: Hassle v Cmr of Patents (1987) 9 IPR 565 at 567–8 . The paragraph in the affidavit refers to a separate document by words to the following effect “Exhibited to me at the time of swearing/affirming this affidavit and marked ABC1 is a true copy of (description of the document)”. The exhibit marking traditionally takes its marking from the initials of the deponent. For example the first exhibit to John Smith's affidavit is referred to as “JS1”. See also Robowash Pty Ltd v Robowash Finance Pty Ltd (2000) 158 FLR 338; 19 ACLC 393; [2000] WASCA 409; BC200007849 at [12] per Kennedy J, Wallwork and Anderson JJ agreeing, citing R E Daniell, Daniells Chancery Forms, 4th ed, Stevens & Sons, London, 1885, at pp 14–15.

Exhibits and annexures to affidavits must be both legible and properly identified. The pages of the affidavit, its annexures and exhibits should all be consecutively numbered: r 35.6(3) — because this facilitates their convenient and efficient use in court.

Exhibits are tendered at the hearing in which the affidavit is read. However, where it would be convenient for the judicial officer expected to hear a matter to peruse the exhibit prior to its tender, consideration should be given to delivered to the chambers of the judicial officer prior to the expected hearing. Ideally bulky exhibits should be provided with tabs for ease of reference: Gotsis v Kizkhan Pty Ltd (NSWSC, Young J, 29 November 1994, unreported). Section 69 of the CPA provides a statutory basis for the court to read affidavits and witness statements prior to the hearing of the proceedings.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.7] r 35.7 Affidavits by persons who cannot read

leg:heading.title: Affidavits by persons who cannot read

p.text: An affidavit made by a blind or illiterate person may not be used unless:
the affidavit bears a certificate referred to in section 27A of the Oaths Act 1900, or
the court is otherwise satisfied:
that the affidavit was read to the deponent in the presence of the person before whom it was made, and
that it appeared to that person that the deponent understood the affidavit.

If the proposed deponent is unable to read either because of physical, linguistic or literacy difficulties, the affidavit must be sworn in circumstances that establish the deponent's understanding and acceptance of responsibility for the accuracy, of the contents of the affidavit. The affidavit should be read to the deponent, if necessary by an appropriate interpreter, before it is sworn. The person taking the affidavit must certify on the affidavit that the contents were read aloud, that the proposed deponent apparently understood them, and duly subscribed the affidavit: s 27A Oaths Act 1900.

Any issue about compliance with the present rule should be raised, at the latest, when the person’s evidence is tendered — and preferably with prior notice. The question of compliance may be established by further evidence, or tested by appropriate cross-examination: Advanced Timber & Hardware (Superstore) Pty Ltd v Kovacevic [2011] NSWSC 366; BC201104007 at [26]–[31] .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.7A] r 35.7A Name of legal practitioner or commissioner for affidavits on affidavit (cf SCR Part 38, rule 2 (4A), (4B) and (5))

leg:heading.title: Name of legal practitioner or commissioner for affidavits on affidavit (cf SCR Part 38, rule 2 (4A), (4B) and (5))

p.text: A legal practitioner who takes and receives an affidavit concerning any matter within the jurisdiction of the court must, by use of a stamp or otherwise, add, legibly below the legal practitioner’s signature, the legal practitioner’s name and address together with the word “barrister” or “solicitor”, as the case requires.

A commissioner for affidavits who takes and receives an affidavit concerning any matter within the jurisdiction of the court, must, by use of a stamp or otherwise, add, legibly below the commissioner’s signature, the commissioner’s name and address together with the words “commissioner for affidavits”.
In this rule, commissioner for affidavits means a person who is authorised by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, under section 27(2) of the Oaths Act 1900, to take and receive affidavits.
[r 35.7A insrt Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[41], effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.7B] r 35.7B Each page of affidavit to be signed

leg:heading.title: Each page of affidavit to be signed

p.text: Each page of an affidavit must be signed by the deponent and by the person before whom it is sworn.
[r 35.7B insrt Amendment 1 of 2005 r 3 and Sch 1[41], effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.8] r 35.8 Affidavit of service not to annex document served (cf SCR Part 38, rule 7A; DCR Part 30, rule 10; LCR Part 25, rule 11)

leg:heading.title: Affidavit of service not to annex document served (cf SCR Part 38, rule 7A; DCR Part 30, rule 10; LCR Part 25, rule 11)

p.text: An affidavit of service of a document that has been served must clearly identify the document, but must not annex a copy of the document unless the document has not been filed.
[subr (1) am Amendment 9 of 2006 r 2 and Sch 1[15], effective 9 June 2006]
An affidavit of service must contain:
a statement as to when, where, how and by whom service was effected, and

a statement, using as nearly as practicable the actual words used by the person to whom the process was delivered, as to what, if anything, that person said, on the occasion of service, concerning the service or the subject matter of the proceedings, and
a statement that the deponent is over the age of 16 years, or is of a named class of persons who by virtue of their status, occupation or otherwise must be over that age.
The approved form is Form 41 : Affidavit of service.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 35.9] r 35.9 Filing of affidavits (cf SCR Part 38, rule 6; DCR Part 30, rule 6; LCR Part 25, rule 6)

leg:heading.title: Filing of affidavits (cf SCR Part 38, rule 6; DCR Part 30, rule 6; LCR Part 25, rule 6)

p.text: Except by leave of the court, an affidavit must not be filed unless it is filed:
in accordance with these rules, or
in accordance with other rules of court applicable to the court in which it is filed, or
in accordance with a practice note applicable to the court in which it is filed.
Legislation cited in [35.9.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 2.1, 2.2, 2.3(j).
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 61(3)(e).

Although the present rule limits the circumstances in which affidavits may be filed, the limit is subject to other provisions of the rules and the usual practices of the court. Rules 2.1 , 2.2 , 2.3(j) and various practice notes (including Practice Note SC Gen 4 — relating to Supreme Court proceedings) permit directions being made for the respective parties to file and serve any affidavit evidence on which they intend to rely. Failure to comply with directions of this kind may result in a party being unable to adduce the relevant evidence at the trial of the proceedings: s 61(3)(e) of the CPA; State Pollution Control Commission v Australian Iron & Steel Pty Ltd (No 2) (1992) 29 NSWLR 487; 75 LGERA 327; BC9203134 ; Bomanite Pty Ltd v Slatex Corp Australia Pty Ltd (1991) 32 FCR 379; 104 ALR 165 .

level.toc-caption: [35.9.10] Leave required to use late served affidavits

heading.title: Leave required to use late served affidavits

p.text: Subject to particular directions of the court, affidavits should be served within a reasonable time before the hearing at which they are to be used. The period that will constitute ‘reasonable time” necessarily depends on the circumstances: see the short discussion in [10.2.5] . An affidavit that has not been served within a reasonable time cannot be used except by leave: see r 10.2 of the UCPR. The considerations that will influence the discretion to grant leave include the degree of notice that has been given and the nature of the material sought to be relied upon. The nature of the material includes its novelty (in relation to the existing contentious evidence and issues in the proceedings) its apparent credibility, whether or not it is in fact likely to contested; and any time the opposing party may require to deal adequately with new material: Lai v Lai (NSWSC, McLelland J, No 3819/91, 9 November 1992, BC9201494) (no confidence in the accuracy of an affidavit sworn the day before the hearing and unsupported by any form of corroboration). Relevant considerations will also include the dictates of justice (see s 58 of the CPA) and whether the opponent can be adequately compensated for any necessary delay in the hearing or conclusion of the proceedings by an order for costs or, indeed, by any other procedural order: Shekleton-Barden v Hogan (NSWSC, McLelland J, No Eq 2407/84, 13 June 1985, unreported, BC8500758). The width of these considerations, as well as the specific powers contained in s 61(3) of the CPA may justify the refusal of leave to use late served affidavit evidence: (See for example Shekleton-Barden v Hogan, above (refusal of leave to rely on 9 affidavits filed and served the day before the commencement of the hearing). In other cases, dictates of justice may be satisfied by delaying the commencement of the hearing to enable the opponent to meet the material served, or commencing the hearing with the proceedings to be subsequently adjourned if the opponent required further time to meet the material.

The procedure relating to the filing and service of affidavits alters from time to time. Documents (including an affidavit) may, if directed, be filed by being handed to a judge's associate. In Beecham (Aust) Pty Ltd v Roque Pty Ltd (1987) 11 NSWLR 1; 89 FLR 238 , the Court of Appeal held that the methods of filing addressed in the SCR were not exclusive and that subject to the concurrence of the judge filing may be effected in any way, such as in court or with the associate. There is power under s 14 CPA to dispense with the requirements of the rules where it is appropriate to do so in the circumstances of the case.

level.toc-caption: [35.9.20] Rules requiring affidavits to be filed

p.text: Legislation cited in [35.9.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR Pt 32, UCPR 1.24, UCPR 12.1, UCPR 14.23, UCPR 14.24, UCPR 16.3, UCPR 16.4, UCPR 16.5, UCPR 16.6, UCPR 16.7, UCPR 16.9, UCPR 26.6, UCPR 27.3, UCPR 31.26, UCPR 36.10, UCPR 36.8, UCPR 37.2, UCPR 37.6, UCPR 38.2, UCPR 39.21, UCPR 39.3, UCPR 39.35, UCPR 39.45, UCPR 43.2, UCPR 5.2, UCPR 5.3, UCPR 5.4, UCPR 50.14, UCPR 51.61, UCPR 55.9, UCPR 7.2.

heading.title: Rules requiring affidavits to be filed

p.text: Various rules of court require affidavits to be filed. These include the following:
UCPR 1.24 — Affidavit of service — constitutional matters.
UCPR 5.2 — Affidavit for discovery to ascertain prospective defendants identity or whereabouts.
UCPR 5.3 — Affidavit for discovery of documents from prospective defendant.
UCPR 5.4 — Affidavit for discovery of documents from other persons.
UCPR 7.2 — Affidavit as to authority to commence proceedings.
UCPR 12.1 — Affidavit where proceedings are discontinued.
UCPR 14.23 — Verification of pleadings.
UCPR 14.24 — Further affidavit as to verification of pleadings.
UCPR 16.3 — Default judgment.
UCPR 16.4 — Default judgment for possession of land.
UCPR 16.5 — Default judgment for return of goods.
UCPR 16.6 — default judgment on liquidated claim.
UCPR 16.7 — Default judgment on unliquidated claim.
UCPR 16.9 — Default judgment for costs alone.
UCPR 26.6 — Default of receivers.
UCPR 27.3 — Certificate on sale of land.
UCPR 31.26 — Direction for further evidence by an expert.
UCPR Pt 32 — Evidence and Procedure (New Zealand) Act 1994 (Commonwealth).
UCPR 36.8 — Judgment for possession of land.
UCPR 36.10 — Filing of a certificate under the Legal Profession Act 1987 or the Legal Profession Act 2004.
UCPR 37.2 — Application for instalment order.
UCPR 37.6 — Variation of an instalment order.
UCPR 38.2 — Application for an Order for Examination.
UCPR 39.3 — Application for Writ of Execution.
UCPR 39.21 — Registration of Writ.
UCPR 39.35 — Application for Garnishee Order.
UCPR 39.45 — Application for a Charging Order.
UCPR 43.2 — Stakeholder’s interpleader.
UCPR 50.14 — Affidavits in respect of appeals.
UCPR 51.61 — Affidavits in support of notice of motion in Court of Appeal.
UCPR 55.9 — Affidavit in support of payment of money into court.
